comments_since_last_sample.body:
As a reminder, this subreddit [is for civil discussion.](/r/politics/wiki/index#wiki_be_civil)

In general, be courteous to others. Debate/discuss/argue the merits of ideas, don't attack people. Personal insults, shill or troll accusations, hate speech, any suggestion or support of harm, violence, or death, and other rule violations can result in a permanent ban. 

If you see comments in violation of our rules, please report them.

 For those who have questions regarding any media outlets being posted on this subreddit, please click [here](https://www.reddit.com/r/politics/wiki/approveddomainslist) to review our details as to our approved domains list and outlet criteria.

***


*I am a bot, and this action was performed automatically. Please [contact the moderators of this subreddit](/message/compose/?to=/r/politics) if you have any questions or concerns.*

Good. When democracy is at stake, use any tool available, no matter how underhanded and unethical. Save the good in America now, let the future debate whether the ends justified the means, at least they'll have debates in a more equitable, democratic America.

“This is a desperate map from a desperate party,” said Adam Kincaid, executive director of the National Republican Redistricting Trust, which coordinates redistricting for the GOP. He called it “America’s most extreme gerrymander.”

Kincaid is trying to suggest that there is something evil/under-handed/nefarious in the Illinois redistricting plan.  As if the new districts in Texas aren't bad. Don't know if the Texas maps are better or worse, but they're bad enough.  Most of the population growth in Texas came from increases in Hispanic and Black populations, but neither of the two new districts will have a majority of 'people of color'.

Instead of pointing at extreme examples of this anti-democratic practice, how about going with a national law requiring that re-districting in *ALL STATES* be done by non-partisan commissions.  

At this point, the whole gerrymandering thing is like the nuclear arms race -- neither side can afford to let the other side get ahead.

A bit of detail:

Texas -- 47% voted Dem, Dems won 36% of House seats  
Illinois -- 47% voted Rep, GOP won 28% of House seats  
California -- 34% voted Rep, GOP won 21% of House seats  
Ohio -- 45% voted Dem, Dems won 25% of House seats  
Maryland -- 32% voted Rep, GOP won 12.5% of House seats (1 of 8)  
Utah -- 38% voted Dem, Dems won 0% of House seats (0 of 4)

State office races are frequently as bad or worse (example, in IL, only 15% of State Senate seats went to the GOP).

To be clear, bi-partisan commissions are no panacea guaranteeing 'proportionate representation' -- see California where 15% of State Senate (3 of 20), 24% of State Assembly (19 of 79) went to GOP in 2020.

But they help reduce the us-vs-them rhetoric.
Until the votes are available to decidedly outlaw partisan gerrymandering, Democrats need to be fighting fire with fire.

Yes, it’s like the filibuster.  You don’t like it, but you can’t get rid of it* and the other side is going to use it so you’d be cutting your nose off to spite your face to not do so as well.

*thanks Manchin and Sinema /s
Good, then. We shouldn't *always* operate at a deliberate disadvantage
If one side refuses to disarm, why should the other? Democrats proposed legislation that would have banned gerrymandering. Zero republicans voted for it.
OK, that is just one state. It won’t be as bad as 2010, but the advantage is still obviously R.

The difference is that Dems put forward the [For The People Act that would prevent gerrymandering](https://www.brennancenter.org/our-work/analysis-opinion/why-people-act-critical-fair-voting-maps).  Republicans filibustered it in The Senate so it couldn’t be voted on.

Both sides are NOT the same.
Good. Now let’s outlaw gerrymandering nationwide.

Gerrymandering to keep a seat is one thing. Splitting a city's black vote into multiple districts of white voters instead of creating a seat to represent a large group of citizens who live there is racist and unacceptable.
If the Supreme Court says political bias is an acceptable consideration in drawing Congressional maps, why wouldn't they?
Good. Tired of us fighting with one hand behind our backs.
